update.description:
This pull request aims in unifying the functions handling message and service publishers/topics for the Discover and Node classes, thus enabling writing code easier and in a more generic fashion.

Some unit tests in `TopicUtils` are missing.
update.title: Generic Refactoring of Discovery/Node class
update.reason: There are still a few options to discuss. We'll work offline in this branch and resubmit when ready.

content.raw: We can use the old `Publisher` with the new `Discovery` API, but it requires a lot of (shared) pointers. This is why I took this "global" `Publisher` decision. I will try keeping the old `Publisher` and having pointers in Topic Storage. I will let you know, when I have something.
content.html: We can use the old Publisher with the new Discovery API, but it requires a lot of (shared) pointers. This is why I took this "global" Publisher decision. I will try keeping the old Publisher and having pointers in Topic Storage. I will let you know, when I have something.

content.raw:
I like the Discovery but I'm not convinced about the Publisher class. It works but it's not 100% clean. We're sharing member variables for two different purposes:

  * `ctrl` is the control address if the publisher is for messages or it's the socket id if the publisher is for services.
  * `msgTypeName` is also shared and can mean the type of a message or the type of the request.

We also have two different flags, `isService` to differentiate between messages and services and `isReal` to distinguish between different type of publishers.

We still have to work out the Publisher. It'll be hard to maintain if we try to force a single class for two or more different purposes.

Can we combine the old `Publisher` with the new `Discovery` API? Maybe instead of having a templated TopicStorage class we can accept parameters of type Publisher. Publisher would be just the base class that all types of Publishers have.
content.html:
I like the Discovery but I'm not convinced about the Publisher class. It works but it's not 100% clean. We're sharing member variables for two different purposes:

  • ctrl is the control address if the publisher is for messages or it's the socket id if the publisher is for services.
  • msgTypeName is also shared and can mean the type of a message or the type of the request.

We also have two different flags, isService to differentiate between messages and services and isReal to distinguish between different type of publishers.

We still have to work out the Publisher. It'll be hard to maintain if we try to force a single class for two or more different purposes.

Can we combine the old Publisher with the new Discovery API? Maybe instead of having a templated TopicStorage class we can accept parameters of type Publisher. Publisher would be just the base class that all types of Publishers have.

content.raw: I changed the way we were unpacking in 7e107c0. Instead of unpacking just the body in each message type, we unpack the whole message which I believe it's more natural. I added a new constructor that accepts a serialized buffer as parameter. 7e107c0
content.html: I changed the way we were unpacking in 7e107c0. Instead of unpacking just the body in each message type, we unpack the whole message which I believe it's more natural. I added a new constructor that accepts a serialized buffer as parameter. 7e107c0

update.description:
This pull request aims in unifying the functions handling message and service publishers/topics for the Discover and Node classes, thus enabling writing code easier and in a more generic fashion.

Some unit tests in `TopicUtils` are missing.
update.title: Generic Refactoring of Discovery/Node class

content.html:
Some comments on removing isReal and allowing only 2 constructors in Publisher (i.e. not allowing fake Publishers) after a small investigation:

  • It needs extra work in order to pass all tests and the functionality/behavior will change. If we remove isReal, then there's a problem with the following condition in Publisher pack:
if (this->ctrl.empty() || this->msgTypeName.empty() ||
      (this->isService && this->repTypeName.empty()))
  {
    std::cerr << "Publisher::Pack() error: You're trying to pack an "
              << "incomplete Publisher:" << std::endl << *this;
    return 0;
  }

Because if we leave it in there, the abstract Publisher's behavior changes. However, once we remove it, the message/service Publisher's behavior changes.
  • I coded the bare-bones of this restructuring. I don't like it at all.
  • Having a private member variable is a lot cleaner and less error-prone.

What do you say?

content.raw: I am on it! I will merge default and make the appropriate changes.
content.html: I am on it! I will merge default and make the appropriate changes.

content.html: Fixed it in cf1c274 .

content.raw:
We should remove them both and create a new one: `TopicPublishers()` with the shared implementation. I just left it as it is, so we could have this discussion.

The `Discovery` is unaware of messages and services. The `_topic` argument contains either `@srv@` or `@msg@` prefix and `infoTopics` can handle it nicely.
content.html:
We should remove them both and create a new one: TopicPublishers() with the shared implementation. I just left it as it is, so we could have this discussion.

The Discovery is unaware of messages and services. The _topic argument contains either @srv@ or @msg@ prefix and infoTopics can handle it nicely.

content.raw:
Most comments are dealt with. Unit tests in `TopicUtils` added. Now investigating whether some more tests are missing.

`isReal` member variable in `Publisher` class could be eliminated. I am trying to find a way to by-pass it.

I have updated the `\brief` to show that this variable is needed because sometimes we use the `Publisher` class just to advertise the existence of one topic and not caring about control address, msg types etc. Look [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/74be3e61f94344772e2f5f0b65376410b7302702/src/Discovery.cc?at=discovery_refactor_generic#Discovery.cc-345) and [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/74be3e61f94344772e2f5f0b65376410b7302702/src/Discovery.cc?at=discovery_refactor_generic#Discovery.cc-518). Those aren't **real** publishers. They just carry information.
content.html:
Most comments are dealt with. Unit tests in TopicUtils added. Now investigating whether some more tests are missing.

isReal member variable in Publisher class could be eliminated. I am trying to find a way to by-pass it.

I have updated the \brief to show that this variable is needed because sometimes we use the Publisher class just to advertise the existence of one topic and not caring about control address, msg types etc. Look here and here. Those aren't real publishers. They just carry information.

update.description:
This pull request aims in unifying the functions handling message and service publishers/topics for the Discover and Node classes, thus enabling writing code easier and in a more generic fashion.

Some unit tests in `TopicUtils` are missing.
update.title: Generic Refactoring of Discovery/Node class

content.raw: In [`Unadvertise`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/3918945792a1e9107d133804be7f1d2dd3121ecd/src/Node.cc#Node.cc-183) method in `Node` class: since we can't know the type of the topic being unadvertised, we have to un-advertise both messages and services or un-advertise them with a certain order (that's what I'm doing). Thus, if a mesage and a service have the same name the behavior is undefined.
content.html: In Unadvertise method in Node class: since we can't know the type of the topic being unadvertised, we have to un-advertise both messages and services or un-advertise them with a certain order (that's what I'm doing). Thus, if a mesage and a service have the same name the behavior is undefined.

content.raw: Could you add to the `\brief` comment of the `Node` class how `@msg/srv@` works and the motivation. If you feel inspired you could do the same with `@partition_name@`. I feel we should describe this information somewhere in the code in plain English.
content.html: Could you add to the \brief comment of the Node class how @msg/srv@ works and the motivation. If you feel inspired you could do the same with @partition_name@. I feel we should describe this information somewhere in the code in plain English.
